title_review: Excellent Mexican restaurant in a romantic area of Madrid
review_preview: This is a lovely and cosy Mexican restaurant in the Austrias area of Madrid, one of the most romantic ones in the Spanish capital. I visited for the first time on a Sunday night so the restaurant was fairly quiet, which created a very nice...
review_full: This is a lovely and cosy Mexican restaurant in the Austrias area of Madrid, one of the most romantic ones in the Spanish capital. I visited for the first time on a Sunday night so the restaurant was fairly quiet, which created a very nice atmosphere. We were greeted as soon as we came in. Service was very polite and made us feel very comfortable. We ordered some guacamole with nachos, quesadillas suizas and taco de tinga. We were presented with a set of complimentary sauces which were delicious and went well with everything we ordered. As a dessert, we had the cheesecake with dulce de leche. Everything was very, very nicely presented. You could see a lot of care had gone into the food and presentation. I have to say the guacamole was one of the best I’ve ever tried, if not the best! I can’t wait to go back to Madrid and go back to this restaurant, it’s a gem and it has been a great discovery!

review_preview: My wife and I ate here this last week on our last night after 4 wonderful days exploring Madrid for the first. Our conceirge at Hotel Gran Ingles managed to get a table for us the same afternoon which was feat onto itself. The service...
review_full: My wife and I ate here this last week on our last night after 4 wonderful days exploring Madrid for the first. Our conceirge at Hotel Gran Ingles managed to get a table for us the same afternoon which was feat onto itself. The service was fantastic, the food everything from classic Madrid style with tapas to start or even great pasta or steaks. And the menu was both in Spanish and English which really helped. I choose a great piece of flounder and my wife had lobster lasagne. Plus starters of shrimp croquettes.  I also ordered fried pig ear to go out on a limb and when I did not care for it they amazingly took it off our bill without my saying anything! Desert was chocolate dipped strawberries and cafe americano. Plus they brought us 2 lovely after dinner drinks with the compliments of the house. The manager you cannot mistake because he looks like Johnny Depp and for those young at heart there is a lounge downstairs for the late night crowd. We will definitely go back next time in Madrid!  Mikael and Karen

review_preview: This place is well worth a visit.  The setting is modern and stylish with attentive, helpful and friendly staff. The wine list is extensive with well priced choices by the bottle and glass; the staff are happy to advise without pushing for the most expensive...
review_full: This place is well worth a visit. The setting is modern and stylish with attentive, helpful and friendly staff. The wine list is extensive with well priced choices by the bottle and glass; the staff are happy to advise without pushing for the most expensive choice. The menu is well balanced for meat and fish, although not many vegetarian options. The courgette appetiser was gorgeous and the crispy pork belly was beautifully presented and tasted even better. The tuna tartare was equally visually appealing and had my tastebuds tingling. In all, this was an excellent meal in an stylish setting all helped along by friendly and attentive staff. It cost €65 for 3 courses and a glass of wine for 2 people - good value for what we had. This is well worth taking the short walk off the beaten tourist trail to visit. Enjoy...

review_preview: This is such a great find in Madrid--terrific food and a great atmosphere, made all the better by the maitre d' Diego who is charming and genuinely seems to want to be sure you have a good time. There was a small confusion about our...
review_full: This is such a great find in Madrid--terrific food and a great atmosphere, made all the better by the maitre d' Diego who is charming and genuinely seems to want to be sure you have a good time. There was a small confusion about our reservation (that took no time), and Diego sent drinks to our table at the end to apologize. The food was a great mix of modern and traditional, with unusual flavors and combinations. I particularly liked the tuna tartare, and for those in Spain longing for something healthy, the Power Bowl salad was just perfect. We had a relaxed evening on the comfortably cushioned seats, great wine, and many interesting tastes. It's also in a fun neighborhood--and great choice all around.

title_review: Owners make this an unforgettable dinner - best classy gem of a restaurant in Madrid
review_preview: Recently, I had the privilege to take a group of professionals to this restaurant for dinner – we were about 24 persons in total. Well, it’s difficult to explain our overall surprise and pleasure at this establishment, however, I’ll try.  Right from the entry, there’s...
review_full: Recently, I had the privilege to take a group of professionals to this restaurant for dinner – we were about 24 persons in total.  Well, it’s difficult to explain our overall surprise and pleasure at this establishment, however, I’ll try. Right from the entry, there’s a glass rectangle in the floor over which you must step to enter. As you look down, you have a bird’s eye view of a private dining room in the restaurant below. This glass area showcases the place where coal, (for heating the building), was delivered in ages past. Yes, this restaurant has an interesting history. Then you proceed through a small but charming wine store to the staircase which takes you one floor below to the restaurant. Mostly done in brick to resemble a beautiful wine cellar, the restaurant is extraordinarily lovely, with elegant touches everywhere – from wall color to decorations to paintings to stiffly starched table cloths & napkins, to striking table settings. Incredibly pleasing and stylishly furnished. The restaurant consists of several gorgeous interconnecting dining rooms The food was absolutely the best part. Executive chef Lourdes Poveda is a culinary genius, she, along with seven other expert & talented chefs prepare your delicious meals. They spare no detail - everything is freshly prepared, elegantly plated (on striking dinner ware ) and lavishly served. Make sure you observe the chic dinner plates, as a different style is used for each course. We selected a tasting menu of 5 courses + dessert and each one was better than the next. At the end, we couldn’t tell which course we liked best…..they were all delightfully delicious. What an amazing treat! Dessert was good too, the best lemon concoction I’ve ever had - one more pleasing surprise at the end! We will remember this place for a long time to come and find every opportunity to visit each time we are in Madrid. By the way, Executive Chef Lourdes owns the restaurant along with her charming husband who is the extremely knowledgeable and attentive sommelier. He hand selects your wine once he knows your preference, and if you don’t know what you want – all the better because are in for a good surprise. He does know his stuff! During the course of your dinner Executive Chef Lourdes visits your table to ensure your satisfaction. She comments on any given course and encourages your questions. She is just as delightful ad the food she prepares. Service was remarkably impeccable – a couple of times, I dropped my napkin on the floor by my feet. Each time it was noticed, retrieved and a fresh one was returned to me on a platter, beautifully folded and served to me with tongs – no human hands touching it! Price is remarkably moderate for this one of a kind gem in Madrid. If you love superb food and outstanding service, you owe it to yourself to visit.

Beautifully presented, and very tasty. If you're an adventurous eater this is an especially great place for you, but even our 13 year old loved it.

review_preview: I know, I’m just allowed to give the maximum of five points for an outstanding dinner. But it was much better, than five points...The idea, to place a restaurant in the cave of a wine merchant is intriguing. The wine cellar itself is just...
review_full: I know, I’m just allowed to give the maximum of five points for an outstanding dinner. But it was much better, than five points... The idea, to place a restaurant in the cave of a wine merchant is intriguing. The wine cellar itself is just a small room, with about 200 different wines, mainly from Spain and France. We startet with a nice glass of Champagne and they talked us into a wine from the Madrid area to accompany our dinner.  Then they walked us down to the restaurant, it was nearly empty (at 9pm), but during the evening, all tables (about 10 tables) were taken. The chef greeted us and we asked her to suggest something. We started with a small amuse bouche, followed with an excellent zucchini flowers in tempura, filled with bacelao, then Bacelao Negro, quail, tournedos with foie gras and as dessert, lemon pie and torrija de panettone. Our wine “Initio” by Las Moradas de San Martin was excellent and for the sweets we had two glasses of Pedro Ximenez and Moscatel plus two coffees and mineral water. We have been to very good restaurants all around the world, but the “LU experience” was one we will never forget: Outstanding cuisine in a cozy atmosphere, excellent wines, very good service for a very fair price (EURO 172 for two persons). Thank you Lourdes for this experience; we will come back for sure!

The next time I visit Madrid, I will definitely dine at Restaurante Las Carboneras de Lu. Highly recommended!!!

title_review: A superb restaurant - a delicious menu;excellent and attentive service.
review_preview: When in Madrid try and dine here - you will not be disappointed.A fabulous experience from start to finish. Sample some wine and admire the selection of wines on offer in the reception.Dine in a beautiful setting in a renovated brick coal cellar...
review_full: When in Madrid try and dine here - you will not be disappointed. A fabulous experience from start to finish.  Sample some wine and admire the selection of wines on offer in the reception. Dine in a beautiful setting in a renovated brick coal cellar hence: 'Las Carboneras' The menu is fantastic and food delicious; it is all presented and explained with passion by Lu the Executive Chef and her team. We even went 'off piste' with the menu ie a selection cheeses and port at the end of our meal; this was accepted without hesitation. Service is excellent, very attentive and professional. We asked the Sommelier to choose some local wines to accompany our food; his choices were excellent for each course. We were celebrating a 50th birthday, but will return again when in Madrid.  Our experience was better than many at Michelin Star establishments here in the UK; at far better value. A superb discovery, that really we would like to keep a secret for ourselves, but Lourdes and her team rightly deserve the recognition. Muchos gracias! xx

May favorite was the dessert, a reconstructed version of lemon pie. The experience was so memorable I returned to nights later with a girlfriend. It was even better the 2nd time around. Whether you dine with a group of 22 or 2...service and attention to detail remains the same.

review_preview: In Madrid for my cousin’s birthday I wanted somewhere that would be the culinary accompaniment to a morning at the Thyssen. Having chosen Las Carbs on the basis of Trip Advisor reviews we were delighted with our choice. You enter through an upscale wine shop...
review_full: In Madrid for my cousin’s birthday I wanted somewhere that would be the culinary accompaniment to a morning at the Thyssen. Having chosen Las Carbs on the basis of Trip Advisor reviews we were delighted with our choice. You enter through an upscale wine shop and descend into a surprisingly light and airy former coal cellar. Like all good restaurants they do the little things really well - three types of lovely bread, great butter, an amuse bouche of warm edamame peas. The cooking is technically excellent and highly skilful - apparently it takes 20 minutes to debone a quail - roughly twice as long as it takes to eat one. The service was delightful, with the lady chef coming out to explain each dish (there were only around twenty covers on a midweek lunchtime, I doubt she can manage this at the weekends). We trusted wine selection the sommelier and were very pleased. We were trying to refuse pudding when the chef said she had a cheesecake with truffle honey. It isn’t on the menu but should be as it is sweet savoury heaven. Prices are where you would expect them to be for cooking at around about the one Michelin star threshold, which is exactly what you get. Will be back when next in Madrid.

review_preview: This is not a place you go with your family for a celebration or just to have a relaxed and enjoyable time. We went there following the good reviews in various sites and above all by looking at the menu in the website. It portrayed...
review_full: This is not a place you go with your family for a celebration or just to have a relaxed and enjoyable time. We went there following the good reviews in various sites and above all by looking at the menu in the website. It portrayed an image closer to an asador/normal restaurant than to a tasting menu place but we were completely off here. On that basis we were disappointed. The place is very uptight, in a good sense though. The service is impeccable and on top of you which is not necessarily what we were looking for on that day. The place itself is elegant and exuding good taste everywhere even though is set in an old coal storage place (hence the name). The food is good, nothing that wowed us though and that really was what we went for. Certainly more on the tasting side of things given the size of portions and the level of prices. This is the kind of place you will go with some business partners to drink some amazing wine (the place claim to have one the best bodegas in Madrid) and eat something good. The star of the place are the wines which you are immediately made aware of as soon as you enter the place. The fact of the matter is that we were not there for the alcohol. So given all this we can only review this place given our expectations and experience which undeniably has always a subjective component.

title_review: Such high hopes....dashed by the attitude of the owner!
review_preview: On arrival into this warm and eclectic restaurant, we were warmly greeted into the ‘wine shop’ upon which the sommelier encouraged us to try some local wines so we could pick a bottle to take to dinner.  Once we chose a delicious and recommended tempranillo,...
review_full: On arrival into this warm and eclectic restaurant, we were warmly greeted into the ‘wine shop’ upon which the sommelier encouraged us to try some local wines so we could pick a bottle to take to dinner. Once we chose a delicious and recommended tempranillo, we were taken downstairs to our table. The staff were great with the actual restaurant and dining room lovely; however, the owner had one almighty attitude problem. We started with a shared cheese platter and was then promptly (and I mean literally not more than 5 minutes) followed with zucchini flowers. Both these dishes were delicious! My partner had the sucking pig for his mains which he thought was fabulous and I had the cod. I double checked with our waitress when ordering that it was a fillet with NO bones and she assured me it was.  My first mouthful I found a large bone so called over our waitress (who unbeknown to us was the owner), who said that it would be impossible for the chef to find all the bones without destroying the fish - so clearly, you’ll get some bones and then walked away. My third mouthful had another bone so I called her over again and asked her to remove my plate as I didn’t want it. There was no apology, no offer for another meal, just an argument in front of the other guests justifying the dish before turning and walking away again!  Once my partner finished eating I asked for the manager but was ignored. As we were getting ready to leave, I again asked for the manager and was told our waitress was the owner. She refused to come over to speak with us, so we left. It was such a shame as the rest of the staff were fantastic but her attitude really ruined our night. I’ve worked in fine dining establishments and would never have spoken to or treated my customers like that. It was embarrassing and I ultimately left hungry. Maybe if we had been a group of 20+ people we would have received the fabulous service that others appear to have had although, having said that, the owner doesn't even bother with the reviews or opinions of diners. Hopefully she'll receive enough negative ones to change her attitude!

Good value and if you go with Fork booking, a real deal. Do not miss it if you are up to a real Indian.

title_review: Great food, great service, quirky interior
review_preview: Visited Purnima Thursday night and felt compelled to write a review as the food was outstanding!Decor - Modern and chic. Very tastefully decorated.Food - To start we ordered onion bhaji’s and were given complimentary mini poppadoms and chutneys. On hearing that my wife...
review_full: Visited Purnima Thursday night and felt compelled to write a review as the food was outstanding! Decor - Modern and chic. Very tastefully decorated. Food - To start we ordered onion bhaji’s and were given complimentary mini poppadoms and chutneys. On hearing that my wife loves spice, the waiter brought over a separate curry paste for her which she thoroughly enjoyed. For mains, we asked for advice and the waiter was very happy to learn about what we like, our spice levels etc. We opted for a chicken tikka masala and a chicken vindaloo. We also ordered boiled rice and roti’s.  When the food arrived, the waiter checked that it was to our satisfaction and I commented that both lovely but one dish could be hotter in the spice department. I want to note that the food was delicious and we were happy but the waiter took the dish away as he said the chef will get it to our likening. On return, the dish was perfect, and we were blown away with how much the waiter really cared and went to the effort he did.  The portion sizes were great also, we were offered our leftovers to take away but as we were moving on to bars, we declined but nice touch. We were also given a complimentary mango drink and jelly sweets, again nice touch. Service - Amazing! Wish we had taken note of the waiters name but he was excellent. Very polite and friendly, even understood our Scottish accents! Overall - When we come back to Madrid we will definitely return, that’s if we don’t go back before we head home! You need to visit as this is one of the better Indian restaurants in Madrid.

title_review: Very good food with a relaxing atmosphere
review_preview: We moved to Madrid 3 weeks ago and needed a break from Spanish food. The food at Purnima was very good. It felt like a family run restaurant: very relax and welcoming. We had the Vegetable Semosa for an appetizer. Be warned: They are very...
review_full: We moved to Madrid 3 weeks ago and needed a break from Spanish food.  The food at Purnima was very good. It felt like a family run restaurant: very relax and welcoming. We had the Vegetable Semosa for an appetizer. Be warned: They are very large. It can/should be shared. We also had the chicken tandoori and chicken curry. Chicken was well cooked. I think the curry could have been more spicy but it was still nice mild.  Overall: food was good, owners/workers were extremely nice, and environment relaxing. Excellent place for a casual dinner.

Even the table next to us didn't get any attention either. No offence but I don't know what the stars were for . When we FINALLY got the staff attention Brian came and we were very disappointed and we explained about the burger and seemed like he didn't care but it was taken off the bill. All in all I WONT be recommending this place to anybody .

We had dinner in the terrace which I must say it was pleasant and we ordered chicken tikka massala and lamb korma, with basmati tice and nan. Although, it wasn't bad I'm surprised to see people saying this is the best Indian restaurant in Madrid. The tikka massala was average with a sauce extremely red which was a bit weird and the sauce a bit too liquid. The lamb korma was tender and not bad taste, but I still think it wasn't the best korma you can try. In the end 26 euros per person, including a dessert to share and a couple of Indian beers

title_review: Like going back to the UK in the 70s
review_preview: Madrid has a poor history of Indian restaurants. I have lived here 16 years and they are hit and miss - mainly miss. Most are stuck in a 70's flock wallpaper time warp and have never had a second thought about modernising either in interior...
review_full: Madrid has a poor history of Indian restaurants. I have lived here 16 years and they are hit and miss - mainly miss. Most are stuck in a 70's flock wallpaper time warp and have never had a second thought about modernising either in interior design or food. Purnima is unfortunately one of those. All the dishes had the same consistency and same colour and the nan bread was stodgy - the menu? All the old favourites. Nothing is very spicy because the Spanish tend not to like spicy (hot) food. Anyone who gave this place 5 stars needs to get out more.....

title_review: Worth a visit. Nice curries-request ´English curry/customer´ if you want something a bit more spicy, great staff.
review_preview: We were a party of 2 having lunch. Overall food is good. Place is really clean. Staff nice and cheery and helpful. Downside, we ordered a bottle of wine which was corked , tasted and smelt dreadful and had to be sent back. I was...
review_full: We were a party of 2 having lunch. Overall food is good. Place is really clean. Staff nice and cheery and helpful. Downside, we ordered a bottle of wine which was corked , tasted and smelt dreadful and had to be sent back. I was told i would have to pay for a replacement but i refused. There was no manager to consult and staff seemed worried about having an unpaid bottle of wine in the system. As none of them drank i couldn´t prove the bad taste to them but i made them smell it and compared it with a same brand but different bottle being used to serve wine by the glass from the bar. It smelt so bad that they eventually gave me another bottle which was fine. I offered them my mobie number if their missing manager wanted to discuss this further.  Apart from that everything was good and i would go back. I´d like to say Hakim was very helpful throughout and speaks really good English as do a few other members of staff.  More detailed info if you need it... There are 3 ´menus´ ( at 11.90, 25 and 35 euros) plus the a la carte. Starters are between 5.50 and 11 euros. Mains between 11.50 ( chicken) to 15 euros ( king prawns dishes). Lamb is around 13 euros. I didn´t have room for dessert so can´t comment on that.  Personally i wasn´t too impressed with the choice on offer in opening price point menu which served bhaji, chicken soup, salad, ( forgot 4th option) and mains such as Dhal, Dhamsak , none of the common more favourable dishes available here but the 25 euros menu showed a lot of promise with bhajis, samosas etc...to choose from and mains such as CTM and madras among others. You also get a veg side dish in this menu along with nan or rice. A dessert or coffee at the end. None of the menus include a drink.  Rice portions are really good. ( 4 euros for plain 5 euros for pilau) Recently we have had to order a 2nd portion of rice - many restaurants are cutting back on portion size - but this time we just ordered 2 straight away as we were really hungry so we were quite surprised when 2 deep pots of rice were delivered to our table so much so we had to bring nearly a whole portion home with us. Nan bread was lovely. Soft , fluffy, freshly cooked. We got 3 medium sized bjajis which were a lovely starter with a choice of 3 sauces, not amazing but ok. We ordered lamb balti and chicken bhuna. Chicken dishes seem to be bigger coming in a wide rounded curry dish where as lamb dishes come in a bucket style pot which has a false base half way up so it seems you get a smaller portion if you order lamb...costs i guess. Anyway both curries were nice, the lamb being the better option but no spice/heat at all even though we asked for ´medium´. As mentioned before the staff were great and took our curries away to make them spicier. Upon returning the smiling waiter said ( inEnglish) please tell the waiter next time that you are English so he can make a note for the chefs who will make you a ´medium´spiced english curry.  More suited for couples, friends and business. Dont think you can get around too easily with a pram and 2 flights of stairs to the loos.
